title: Parents of adorable baby girl battling rare disease in desperate bid to raise £500,000 for 'wonder drug'
text:
Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Comments THE desperate parents of a baby girl suffering from a rare disease are crowdfunding to raise £500,000 for life-saving treatment. 
Three-month old Inaaya Shabbir, from Birmingham, has Wolmans Disease – a rare genetic disease that causes malnutrition. Vici Beardsworth 4 Baby Inaaya needs life-saving treatment for Wolmans disease 
The disease stops babies from breaking down certain fats within the body as they are missing a specific enzyme. 
It is so rare it affects one in every 350,000 newborns. 
Adorable Inaaya’s parents, Ibrar and Amber, are desperately trying to raise money for her to receive treatment. 
Inaaya needs regular doses of a drug called sebelipase alfa, which replaces the vital enzyme she is missing. Vici Beardsworth She has been receiving weekly treatments of a life-saving drug but now her family needs to pay for it as it is not on the NHS Vici Beardsworth Inaaya is missing a vital enzyme that breaks down fats in the body 
The drug was approved in the US and Europe in 2015 under the trade name Kanuma. 
Inaaya has been given three months treatment for free by the drug manufactures, but now her family need to pay for her continued treatment as it is not included on the NHS. 
She needs a weekly dose of the drug, which costs an expensive £6,500 a pop, according to close family friend Vici Beardsworth. 
She has set up a Just Giving page to raise the much-needed money for little Inaaya. 
So far, £6,749 has been raised. She wrote on the page: “I could sit and cry for Inaaya and her family, but I wont sit idle. 
“This damn disease is ripping a family apart and has left us broken. 
“I am hoping to raise enough money to help fund Inaaya’s treatment and help her get the medication she needs. 
“The treatment is £500,000,I know that seems like an impossible sum but I must take a shot at this monster.” WHAT IS WOLMANS DISEASE? 
Wolmans disease is a rare inherited condition involving the breakdown and use of fats and cholesterol in the body. 
In affected people, harmful amounts of lipids accumulate in the spleen, liver, bone marrow, small intestine, small hormone-producing glands on top of each kidney and lymph nodes. 
Babies with Wolmans disease are healthy and active at birth but soon develop signs and symptoms of the disorder.
